Hi Gary,
Labour did oppose the introduction of PCCs in 2012. A lot of the concern at the time was about the politicisation of the operational delivery of policing. That hasn’t happened, and since 2016 Labour policy has been to retain PCCs.
An important part of the role of the PCC is to hold the police to account, to scrutinise their work, ranging from how well they support victims of sexual offences, for example, to ensuring they are more visible and accessible.
But how is the PCC held to account? An important mechanism is the Police and Crime Panel, which was specifically set up for that purpose. However, I am keen to develop numerous ways of engaging with the residents of Thames Valley, both in person and online, to listen to their concerns and represent them as well as possible.

(Press release 1st Feb 2024)
A BBC investigation has revealed how Newbury based police officers made sickening comments about an assault victim while watching body-worn video showing her groin. Police had arrested the woman in Newbury Town Centre last year, after mistakenly believing that she had committed an assault. She had, in fact, been the victim. On the way back to the police station she suffered from a seizure, which left her chest and genitals exposed. Officers watching footage of the incident insulted her looks, used derogatory language about her genitals and discussed what they would need to be paid to sleep with her.
Labour’s candidate for Police and Crime Commissioner in Thames Valley, Tim Starkey, says the incident raises serious questions about the police force’s approach to rooting out misogynist behaviour. He asks:
“Why did it take a police investigation for Thames Valley Police to report this case to the Independent Office for Police Conduct? Why were details of this misconduct kept from the public eye? What were the circumstances in which the student officer reporting this came to be dismissed?”
Tim added “Holding the police to account goes to the heart of the role of Police and Crime Commissioner. In my work as a barrister prosecuting rape and domestic abuse cases I see how vital it is that victims have trust in the police. I have worked with incredibly dedicated and professional officers. However, it is vital that misogynistic attitudes and behaviour are rooted out, so that victims can approach police with confidence”.
Notes to editor:
Link to BBC story Police officers mock body-worn video of semi-naked woman – BBC News

1. Within policing overall, what are your priorities, if you are elected PCC? What are the resource implications?
My mission will be to rebuild trust in police. I would do this through a) Strengthening neighbourhood policing. Whilst there have been recent increases, just a year ago community policing had been decimated to a point that there were only about 150 police officers across 108 Neighbourhood “teams” in Thames Valley b) an overhaul of the vetting and misconduct procedures so that victims of domestic abuse or sexual offences can have trust in the officers dealing with their cases.
I would focus on:
- Reducing violence against women and girls. In my work as a criminal barrister, I see first hand the impact on victims of lengthy delays and poor communication from the police.
- Education, mentoring and targeted interventions to steer young people away from gangs, county lines and knife crime.
- Making our roads safe for all users. Thames Valley was one of only 2 police areas in the country to see an increase in road traffic incidents last year.
- Stopping the surge in shoplifting (up 37% in the last year) by working with businesses to identify prolific offenders and ban them from crime hotspots.
- Working with our thriving local tech industry to help keep us safe online.
2. Within roads policing, what are your priorities, if you are elected PCC? Are there any specific initiatives that you plan? What are the resource implications?
I fully support the “vision zero” aim to end deaths and serious injuries on Oxfordshire’s roads by 2050. Whilst technological change has, long term, made the roads safer for those driving cars, there has not been a corresponding fall in fatalities and serious injuries for cyclists and pedestrians. So it is urgent to ensure the protection of all road users.
Speeding remains the biggest factor in road deaths, (see my response to the next question). However, drink and drug driving causes nearly 15% of road deaths. As PCC I will call for the police to be given the power to conduct random breathalyser checks near night clubs, pubs etc, as happens in most EU countries.
I will extend the use of 3rd party reporting of dangerous driving, mobile phone use etc. Used widely, this has a significant deterrent effect.
Dangerous parking – for example near junctions or forcing those with mobility scooters into the road or putting children walking to school at risk – is an issue people across Thames Valley have raised with me. Introducing the Park Safe scheme (piloted in Sheffield) would making it far easier for residents to report and upload evidence of dangerous parking to police.
3. Speeding is highlighted as the greatest danger in the survey, and post-investigation recording. How will you tackle speeding, on both urban and rural roads? What are your views on 20mph speed limits?
I welcome the introduction of 20mph speed limits, when done with support from local residents. However, the enforcement of 20mph limits has been almost non-existent. Having consulted with councillors across Thames Valley I am in favour of local councils being given the power to enforce 20 mph speed limits themselves.
Average speed cameras are an important tool that should be used across Thames Valley. Whilst I welcome the fact that in the last couple of months TVP has finally begun installing average speed cameras, in other forces they have been a widespread and common part of enforcement for years.
Finally, an important part of the mix is in making the work of volunteer Speedwatch groups more effective, in collaboration with neighbourhood policing (see my answer to the next question).
4. Law enforcement can be improved by working in partnerships and with communities. How will you work with other organisations and citizens to reduce crime if you are elected?
The Police and Crime Commissioner is uniquely placed to forge partnerships between police and organisations in wider society. One such vital partnership is with schools: whether it comes to messages about knife crime or about the meaning of consent in healthy sexual relationships.
Another example, is in relation to tackling the growth of online fraud – something traditional policing has proved ill equipped to deal with. I want to build partnerships with local tech firms to provide volunteering opportunities for their employees to give advice to small businesses, or through charities such as Age UK.
A final example relates to volunteer Speedwatch groups. They can be made more effective by:
- Sometimes working alongside neighbourhood officers using speed guns so that passing motorists can’t assume they are only at risk of a warning letter if speeding.
- Getting letters out to speeding motorists faster, it currently often takes 6 weeks.
- Follow the West Berkshire example of local authority involvement to facilitate a data led approach of where Speedwatch groups should target their activity.

I live with my family in Chalfont St Giles, Bucks. I have worked for the last 22 years as a barrister, both prosecuting and defending in all types of cases from speeding to murder, from rape to drug importation. This range of experience has shown me how all too often the criminal justice system fails people, and what needs to change.
At the heart of my campaign is the need to rebuild trust in policing. Over the last few months I have been travelling widely across Thames Valley, listening to residents’ concerns over the lack of visible, neighbourhood policing, road safety, the surge in shoplifting, knife crime, the explosion of internet fraud and improving the response of the criminal justice system to offences of Violence against Women and Girls.
Please get in touch to share your views or if you wish to volunteer to help with my campaign.

Video of me in Woodley talking about shoplifting:
Shoplifting has soared by 25% in the last year, costing the UK around £1 billion. This is far from a victimless crime. As a consequence, in the middle of the cost of living crisis we are all paying higher prices, and it has become so bad that some shops are struggling to survive. Here are 5 actions Labour would take to tackle this:
- Restore visible neighbourhood policing to deter thieves and reassure the public.
- Work with businesses to identify and tackle crime “hotspots” and repeat offenders.
- Introduce “respect orders” to ban prolific offenders from particular shopping malls or town centres.
- End the Tory change to the law that re-categorised thefts under £200 leading to them all too often not being prosecuted.
- Restore funding for drug treatment programmes to tackle one of the root causes of the problem, as 70% of those arrested for shoplifting are addicted to Class A drugs.
Dear Tim,
As a retired magistrate I agree with you that shoplifting is not a “victimless” crime. But your proposals will be met with the usual rebuffs from the Conservative Party.
Visible neighbourhood policing – not enough police.
Banning persistent offenders – see above: would need to be policed.
Recategorising offences – more work for the police and the courts.
Funding for drug abuse programmes – funding where from?
So I think that the problem is far deeper than the rather superficial remedies that you propose. We have to go far deeper and be prepared to spend much more on education from the nursery up. It is about changing society’s attitudes to wrong doing.

Stephen,
Thank you very much for getting in touch. I think you make an excellent point that policing and criminal justice solutions alone are not enough. A “whole society” approach is needed for tackling many different types of crime, which is focussed on changing attitudes. This is true of shoplifting, but also relates, for example, to tackling violence against women and girls.
In terms of the “usual rebuffs”:
– On “visible policing” it isn’t simply about total police numbers, it’s about how police are deployed. Since 2010 the proportion of police involved in neighbourhood policing has reduced from 19% to 12%. It’s also about “churn”. The boom and bust of police numbers under the Tories (getting rid of 20,000 officers, then recruiting 20,000 new ones has contributed to a lack of consistency in neighbourhood policing teams.
– Banning offenders would need to be policed, but would give the police an immediate tool in dealing with the small number of persistent offenders who commit the majority of shoplifting offences. I had a fascinating conversation with the manager of a Co-op store that has sadly been repeatedly targeted by the same offenders. In the situation he described I believe banning orders would make the police job easier and protect his store.
– I think it was a mistake for the Tories to re-categorise theft under £200 in 2014. I don’t actually think that prosecution is always the right answer for every low level shoplifter. There will be occasions when a conditional caution and restorative justice would be appropriate. It depends on the type of shoplifter: many are drug addicts, some are in very difficult financial circumstances, some are kids messing around and others are part of organised gangs. The problem is that I am frequently told that often the police simply don’t investigate at all.
– On drug treatment. This largely falls outside the PCC’s direct control. However, I think it is important to use the role as a platform to put pressure on other bodies to do their part in reducing crime. Up until 2012, the amount of money each council had to spend on drug and alcohol treatment services was ringfenced, until the government decided to give councils autonomy overt how much they spent on this. This has been a disaster. IN 2013/14 councils spent a total of £828 million on substance misuse services.in 2023/24 they have budgeted to spend £617 m. In Windsor and Maidenhead there has been a reduction of nearly 50%. Of course, money is tight for everything. However, I believe that highlighting this issue and making it a priority is important.
– I would add that there has been a re-distribution of resources under the current PCC away from higher crime urban areas eg. with very big cuts to the community safety fund payments to Reading and Slough. I think it is important to be a PCC for the whole of Thames Valley and focus resources where crime is highest.

[Press release Feb 2024]
Tim Starkey, Labour’s candidate in May’s election for a new Police and Crime Commissioner in Thames Valley has expressed great concern at ongoing failings to protect women and girls in the region. Under Clare’s law – named after Clare Wood, who was murdered in 2009 by her ex-boyfriend George Appleton – people have a right to ask police whether a partner or ex-partner has a history of abusive behaviour.
Following an investigation by the Guardian, it has emerged that one of the police forces doing least to protect women was Thames Valley where the disclosure rate was 18.43% in the two years to March 2023, less than half the national average.
Nicole Jacobs, the Domestic Abuse Commissioner for England and Wales said that while information provided under Clare’s law was “potentially life-saving”, rejected or poorly conducted applications could give “a false sense of security which further endangers the victim”.
His Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary has separately sent warnings over Clare’s law to Thames Valley, after inspections highlighted problems including resourcing issues and long delays.
Tim, a local barrister, said that especially at a time of escalating levels of violence against women and girls, this was completely unacceptable and left hundreds of people at risk. “In my work I see the consequences of these failures. We need much more focus on protecting women and girls from violence, whether it is in the streets or in their homes. I work with police all the time and know that officers are dedicated to providing as good a service as possible. Labour will improve their training and resourcing to ensure they can and will improve.”

The starting point for taking over the role of Police and Crime Commissioner is to understand how well or badly Thames Valley Police is serving the public and tackling crime, and what needs to change.
Inspection
An objective assessment comes from the regular inspections carried out by His Majesty’s Inspectorate of Constabulary and Fire and Rescue Service (HMICFRS). The most recent PEEL report (judging Police Effectiveness, Efficiency and Legitimacy) was in December. Here is a link:
Here is a short video explaining the changes in the inspections since Matthew Barber became PCC:
Is crime going up or down?
Conservative Party leaflets in this election have cherry picked statistics to support their narrative and leaving out, for example, the fact that shoplifting has soared by 37.5% in the year to March 2024. Or that robbery of business premises has increased by 120% in the same period.
Equally, when it is claimed that crime across Thames Valley has fallen by 1.8% in the last year, it should be noted that:
- The year before crime increased by 4% in Thames Valley. So crime has gone up not down in the time that Matthew Barber has been Police and Crime Commissioner.
- These figures do not include fraud.
Taking a long view, the best description is that the nature of crime is changing. Many types of crime have, in fact, been declining since the mid-1990s. On the other hand, online grooming has quadrupled since 2016 and internet based fraud is the type of crime we are all most likely to experience.
Here is a link to the statistics:
Summary of notifiable offences in Thames Valley March 2023 To February 2024
What about police numbers?
There has been a boom and bust of police numbers since 2010.
First, the Conservative / Lib Dem coalition government cut police by 20,000. Then, in 2019 the Conservatives decided to recruit 20,000 more police. The Conservatives claim that there are more police in Thames Valley than ever before. However, this is not true per head of population. Thames Valley has the fastest growing population of any police force anywhere in the country outside London (Metropolitan Police).
Conservative leaflets also claim to have “doubled neighbourhood policing”. However, it should be noted that this is not over the time the Conservatives have been in charge, or even over the time that Matthew Barber has been Police and Crime Commissioner. Instead, this is from a point last year when neighbourhood police teams had been reduced to just 150 officers, for 108 neighbourhood police teams. Crucially, it also doesn’t take into account PCSOs. Neighbourhood teams are made up of a mix of officers and PCSOs. However, PCSOs have been reduced from 472 in Thames Valley in 2015 to 252 now. So neighbourhood teams have not been doubled in strength.

The starting point for understanding the role is that the police need civilian oversight. Nobody would argue that the police should have tax raising powers – so it’s down to the PCC to set the police precept (the part of your council tax that goes to the police). Nobody would argue that the police alone should decide what the priorities for policing should be – so it’s down to the PCC to be the voice of the public in setting the police and crime plan for the area. Equally nobody would say the police should police themselves. So its for the PCC to hold the police to account.
But the role goes wider than just the police. The PCC has responsibility for victims services, crime prevention and partnership working with a whole range of agencies.
Its often argued that the role shouldn’t be political. However, it seems to me that issues of taxation, public money and public safety are inherently political. What is most important is make sure the operational side doesn’t become political. For this reason, the PCC can’t make operational decisions, such as to who to arrest for example.

[Press release from March 2024]
On the third anniversary of the murder of Sarah Everard, Tim Starkey, Labour’s candidate for Police and Crime Commissioner, is supporting Labour’s call for mandatory national vetting standards for police.
Following a report into the murder of Sarah Everard by serving Met police officer Wayne Cozens, Labour has called for urgent reform to vetting and misconduct procedures in all police forces, including Thames Valley.
The Angiolini inquiry has found that the serving Met Police officer Wayne Couzens who kidnapped, raped and murdered Sarah Everard had been reported to police eight times for indecent exposure. He was also alleged to have committed other sexual offences over a number of years.
Labour’s candidate for Thames Valley Police and Crime Commissioner warns “another Wayne Cozens could be operating in plain sight”.
Mr Starkey described as shocking the multiple failures in investigating Mr Couzens’ indecent exposure offences, which could have stopped him in his tracks, adding “better training and higher priority must be given to tackling this type of offending that all too often escalates, with tragic consequences.”
Labour has called for mandatory national vetting standards, so no-one with a history of domestic abuse or sexual offending would be allowed to join the police and any officer facing an investigation for such offences would be automatically suspended.

Speeding remains the biggest factor in road deaths, (see my response to the next question). However, drink and drug driving causes nearly 15% of road deaths. As PCC I will call for the police to be given the power to conduct random breathalyser checks near night clubs, pubs etc, as happens in most EU countries.
I will extend the use of 3rd party reporting of dangerous driving, mobile phone use etc. Used widely, this has a significant deterrent effect.
Dangerous parking – for example near junctions or forcing those with mobility scooters into the road or putting children walking to school at risk – is an issue people across Thames Valley have raised with me. Introducing the Park Safe scheme (piloted in Sheffield) would making it far easier for residents to report and upload evidence of dangerous parking to police.
3. Speeding is highlighted as the greatest danger in the survey, and post-investigation recording. How will you tackle speeding, on both urban and rural roads? What are your views on 20mph speed limits?
I welcome the introduction of 20mph speed limits, when done with support from local residents. However, the enforcement of 20mph limits has been almost non-existent. Having consulted with councillors across Thames Valley I am in favour of local councils being given the power to enforce 20 mph speed limits themselves.
Average speed cameras are an important tool that should be used across Thames Valley. Whilst I welcome the fact that in the last couple of months TVP has finally begun installing average speed cameras, in other forces they have been a widespread and common part of enforcement for years.
Finally, an important part of the mix is in making the work of volunteer Speedwatch groups more effective, in collaboration with neighbourhood policing (see my answer to the next question).
4. Law enforcement can be improved by working in partnerships and with communities. How will you work with other organisations and citizens to reduce crime if you are elected?
The Police and Crime Commissioner is uniquely placed to forge partnerships between police and organisations in wider society. One such vital partnership is with schools: whether it comes to messages about knife crime or about the meaning of consent in healthy sexual relationships.
Another example, is in relation to tackling the growth of online fraud – something traditional policing has proved ill equipped to deal with. I want to build partnerships with local tech firms to provide volunteering opportunities for their employees to give advice to small businesses, or through charities such as Age UK.
A final example relates to volunteer Speedwatch groups. They can be made more effective by:
- Sometimes working alongside neighbourhood officers using speed guns so that passing motorists can’t assume they are only at risk of a warning letter if speeding.
- Getting letters out to speeding motorists faster, it currently often takes 6 weeks.
- Follow the West Berkshire example of local authority involvement to facilitate a data led approach of where Speedwatch groups should target their activity.
